name: TX 8000
keyboard: QWERTY, 45 rubber keysBasic instructions and graphic symbols
ports: Tape-recorder (600 bauds)RF video outComposite video out (DIN)Memory upgrade portExpansion port
description: This TX-8000 is exactly identical as the Video Technology Laser 200. It was sold only in the UK where it was, for a short time, the less expensive colour home computer.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FROM WALKMAN TO M5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This US dealer advert says that the designer of the M5, Toshiaki Kamijo was before the Walkman inventor in Sony CIE.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Chuck Hunkle, who worked at MSI in 1977-79, kindly sent us the complete 1978 MSI catalog. All the pages are shown in the following pictures.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>In July 1985, California Digital sold the Tano at $99. The price would decrease down to $35 while stock last.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NLS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert from Non-Linear Systems, dated July, 1982 for the KAYCOMP II that was not still called KAYPRO. <br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"><b>A WORD ABOUT NLS</b><br> Non-Linear Systems, inc. is the originator of the digital voltmeter and an innovative leader in the field of electronic test equipment.<br> Organized in 1952, NLS has been a major supplier of digital voltmeters and ratiometers to large corporations in the aerospace industry. Since 1972, NLS has been consumer directed, providing small, portable multimeters, oscilloscopes, counters, frequency meters, temperature meters. And now, NLS has entered the world of computers with one though - to provide the best value in a small, business, scientific and family computer.</font><br><br> Standard software delivered with the KAYCOMP II: <br><br> - <b>CP/M 2.2</b> - operating system<br> - <b>S/BASIC</b> - Structured Basic compiler<br> - <b>PROFIT PLAN</b> - Electronic worksheet<br> - <b>SELECT</b> - Complete word processing system<br> - <b>TEACH</b> - A self-teaching guide to SELECT </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our all-in-one BMC IF-800 computer is easier for dealers to sell, customers to buy and OEM to use in their systems...<br> ... You can upgrade to a 16 bit CPU which offers IBM PC compatible MS-DOS and CP/M-86...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for correspondance courses using MPF-1 computers.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"There music puts in it"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRONG WOOMAN(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Don't beleive this advert!<br> Please, look carefully at the quite horizontal shoulders of the woman who carries the Osborne (about 12 Kg). Either she is a champion of wrestling, or the Osborne case is empty. <br><br> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SHOW BAG</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert introduced three new Digital professional computers: the <b>Professional 300 Series</b>, the <b>DECmate II</b>, and the <b>Rainbow 100</b> <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">All that personal computers needed were a few professional standards. <br><br> Until now, manufacturer have made personal computers that were a hopeful compromise between home and use business. But now, Digital Equipment Corporation offers the first personal computers designed and built strictly for professional use. And since different professionals have different needs, Digital is introducing not one, but three personal computers made to professional standards.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
